article.title: Machine Learning Friendly Set Version of Johnson-Lindenstrauss Lemma

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main observation about the dependence of reduced dimensionality (n\') on sample size (m) as shown in Figure 1?
choices: Both the explicit and implicit n\' decrease with increasing m.
The explicit n\' remains constant while the implicit n\' increases with increasing m.
Both the explicit and implicit n\' increase with increasing m, with the implicit n\' diverging from the explicit one.
The explicit n\' increases linearly while the implicit n\' increases exponentially with increasing m.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 2 depicts the relationship between reduced dimensionality (n\') and acceptable failure rate (ε). What trend is observed in the figure?
choices: Both explicit and implicit n\' increase linearly with increasing ε.
Both explicit and implicit n\' decrease with increasing ε, with the implicit n\' approaching the explicit one.
The explicit n\' stays constant while the implicit n\' increases exponentially with increasing ε.
Both explicit and implicit n\' decrease exponentially with increasing ε.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 3 shows the dependence of reduced dimensionality (n\') on the error range (δ). What is the significant observation from this figure?
choices: Both explicit and implicit n\' increase linearly with increasing δ.
The explicit n\' decreases exponentially while the implicit n\' decreases linearly with increasing δ.
Both explicit and implicit n\' decrease with increasing δ, reaching a saturation point and converging at extreme δ values.
The explicit n\' remains constant while the implicit n\' decreases logarithmically with increasing δ.

multiple_choice_question.text: Formula (4) provides an explicit calculation for reduced dimensionality (n\'). What is a key characteristic of this formula in comparison to the implicit calculation?
choices: Formula (4) requires iterative computation while the implicit calculation provides a direct result.
Formula (4) does not depend on the original dimensionality (n) while the implicit calculation does.
Formula (4) is significantly more computationally expensive than the implicit calculation.
Formula (4) is only applicable for very specific data distributions, unlike the more general implicit calculation.
